summary_reasoning: Explicitness is decent: the report states key drivers near the forecasts (revenue growth ~7–9%/“~8%,” operating margin ~45%, WACC 9.5% with components, terminal growth 2%, tax ~24%, and 2025 revenue/EPS). Specificity is partial-to-solid for those items (units and horizons are given), but material bank-specific levers (credit cost/provisions, NII/NIM path beyond 2025, deposit betas, share count) are unstated. Justification is partial: some inputs reference management guidance (2025 NII $95.5B) and historical data, and WACC components are listed, but there’s little triangulation vs multi-year history or peers, and no evidence supporting 45% operating margin or 24% tax rate. Consistency is weak: there are at least two unresolved numeric contradictions—(1) claiming “trades near book value” while stating implied P/B ~1.9x, and (2) stating “Revenue CAGR ~8% (2022–29)” while the table (128.7→250) implies ~10% CAGR. Sensitivity analysis is inadequate: only a single WACC sensitivity (±$20 per 100 bp) and a qualitative ±10–20% macro swing are provided; there are no quantified scenarios for NII/NIM, margins, or credit costs. Given multiple contradictions and absence of stress-testing on core banking drivers, the overall quality of assumptions is poor.

assumptions_extracted.quote: We estimate FY2025 revenue around $190B and EPS ~$22, rising to ~$26 by 2029
A weighted average cost of capital around 9–10% is plausible (β ≈1.2–1.3, 3% risk-free, 6–7% equity premium).

contradictions.description: States 'Implied 2025 P/B~1.9×' yet 'At the current price, JPMorgan trades near book value'
Claims 'Revenue CAGR ~8% (2022–29)' but table shows 128.7→250, implying ~10% CAGR

unjustified_parameters: WACC 9.5% not tied to market contemporaries beyond listed components
